channel.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
channel.description:
So I recently got a new computer, and am loving it. However, for one of my monitors I'm using a TV.
Problem is, the TV can go up to 1080p, 1920 x 1080. BUT it looks like shit. The task bar (The shit with the start menu) is like 75% off screen, and the text is not very legible. I can resize it using the NVIDIA Control Panel, but it still doesn't look good.
Right now I have it on 1080p, 1366 x 768. Everything fits fine and I can read everything. But it just looks a little pixelly. Anyone know what the best resolution settings are for this? It's a Sony Bravia TV (like 30 inches).

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

1366x768 on a 32" display is quite a low PPI, it’s naturally going to lack a lot of detail in comparison to a smaller PC monitor even at the same res.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:45, topic:552260”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671176.msg4494803#msg4494803 date=1441135748]

… The current settings are what look best. And I don’t lose any of the display. I thought I stated this.

Read what I said properly. If the display quality is fine but your still having problems with the display getting cut, scale using windows (I don’t mean change resolution)

My current settings are fine. There is nothing being cut off. The only problem (Which occurs on all resolution settings) is the text doesn’t show up as clear as it could/should.
[/quote]The problem is clearly with your tv but if you can’t get into pc-mode and have tried turning off all the after-effects then there’s nothing else to suggest.[/quote]

Yeah… The topic was “Solved” back when I said this:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:19, topic:552260”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=671176.msg4494659#msg4494659 date=1440978956]
try using catalyst to change the screen resolution on the tv itself, then check your tv for a widescreen/theater mode. it’s not always the aspect ratio
[/quote]
The screen is fit fine right now
Only problem left is that text isn’t that clear and can be hard to read.[/quote]
But I mean…

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

my-swagger:

Instead of messing around with the TV settings, set it to whatever looks the best (regardless of how much of the display you lose), then set the size through windows to fit?

… The current settings are what look best. And I don’t lose any of the display. I thought I stated this.

Davidi2:

When you say “lose” what do you mean?

Display offset, the start bar gets cut off by the end of the screen when on 1280x720.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

Davidi2:

When you say “lose” what do you mean?

Most likely offsets.

Instead of messing around with the TV settings, set it to whatever looks the best (regardless of how much of the display you lose), then set the size through windows to fit?

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:38, topic:552260”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=671176.msg4494788#msg4494788 date=1441118530]

Which on there it says the tv can use 1366 x 768 1080i.

So your TV screen resolution isn’t 1920*1080… So what’s the big deal? Of course it’ll look terrible.

When it comes to screen non-alignment, you’ll want to fiddle with aspect ratio on your TV, there’s usually a button for this or it’s buried in some menu under display. Try and force 16:9.
[/quote]
The “deal” is that when I set the settings to what new egg says, I lose parts of the screen. That’s actually why I changed it to a higher resolution.
You also must have missed the part where I said it’s already at 16:9. The text also doesn’t look good on 1366 x 768.

Try setting your resolution to 1280x720 for the TV and see how it looks

I lose almost the entire start bar if I set it to that.

Right now it’s at 1080i, 1768x992 and it seems to be the best I can get it.[/quote]When you say “lose” what do you mean?

Read full topic

Which on there it says the tv can use 1366 x 768 1080i.
[/quote]

So your TV screen resolution isn’t 1920*1080… So what’s the big deal? Of course it’ll look terrible.

When it comes to screen non-alignment, you’ll want to fiddle with aspect ratio on your TV, there’s usually a button for this or it’s buried in some menu under display. Try and force 16:9.[/quote]
The “deal” is that when I set the settings to what new egg says, I lose parts of the screen. That’s actually why I changed it to a higher resolution.
You also must have missed the part where I said it’s already at 16:9. The text also doesn’t look good on 1366 x 768.

Davidi2:

Try setting your resolution to 1280x720 for the TV and see how it looks

I lose almost the entire start bar if I set it to that.

Right now it’s at 1080i, 1768x992 and it seems to be the best I can get it.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

sk8rdude461:

Which on there it says the tv can use 1366 x 768 1080i.

So your TV screen resolution isn’t 1920*1080… So what’s the big deal? Of course it’ll look terrible.

When it comes to screen non-alignment, you’ll want to fiddle with aspect ratio on your TV, there’s usually a button for this or it’s buried in some menu under display. Try and force 16:9.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:34, topic:552260”]I cba to read all the rest of the topic, but based on the OP:

Right now I have it on 1080p, 1366 x 768.

Check the actual TV specs to see what its numbers are; it’s possible that the 1920x1080 is upscaled which is what caused the sizing issues, depending on how old it is. “Sony Bravia” isn’t really clear enough.

Here’s an example of a 32in sony bravia that is designed for 720p
http://www.amazon.com/Sony-BRAVIA-KDL32EX340-32-Inch-Black/dp/B008HYQ7ZI[/quote]
I found mine using it’s model number:

newegg.com

Sony BRAVIA 32" 720p 60Hz LCD HDTV KDL-32BX310 - Newegg.com

Buy Sony BRAVIA 32" 720p 60Hz LCD HDTV KDL-32BX310 with fast shipping and top-rated customer service.Once you know, you Newegg!


Which on there it says the tv can use 1366 x 768 1080i.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:31, topic:552260”]ClearType is Windows.
Right click desktop > Display settings > Advanced display settings > ClearType text.
You will go through a 5-process setup for all* connected displays

as for the hard reset, try this:
Turn off the TV. Point the remote at the device.
Press [Display], [5], [Volume Up] then turn the TV on.
Follow on-screen menu to find the factory reset options.

If that didn’t work, try getting me a model/serial number[/quote]
I found the ClearType in a different way… not sure why my right click menu is different.

Oh and that factory reset just made things much worse. XD thanks.

Edit:
Changed some settings in the tv… Better than before but not perfect.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

ClearType is Windows.
Right click desktop > Display settings > Advanced display settings > ClearType text.
You will go through a 5-process setup for all* connected displays

as for the hard reset, try this:
Turn off the TV. Point the remote at the device.
Press [Display], [5], [Volume Up] then turn the TV on.
Follow on-screen menu to find the factory reset options.

If that didn’t work, try getting me a model/serial number

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:29, topic:552260”]Is it an LCD or LED?

if LCD try turning on ClearType and doing a hard-reset on the TV itself[/quote]
That option doesn’t exist so I’m going with it’s an LED tv.

Read full topic

item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:27, topic:552260”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671176.msg4494663#msg4494663 date=1440980034]

try using catalyst to change the screen resolution on the tv itself, then check your tv for a widescreen/theater mode. it’s not always the aspect ratio

The screen is fit fine right now
Only problem left is that text isn’t that clear and can be hard to read.
[/quote]could you maybe take a picture with your phone or something?[/quote]

Picture of TV:

r7PHP72.jpg2592×1936

Picture of monitor:
1g1PYNA.jpg2592×1936

Notice how the font on the monitor is cleaner.

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:25, topic:552260”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671176.msg4494724#msg4494724 date=1441044090]

try using catalyst to change the screen resolution on the tv itself, then check your tv for a widescreen/theater mode. it’s not always the aspect ratio

The screen is fit fine right now
Only problem left is that text isn’t that clear and can be hard to read.

I had the same problem as you and this topic inspired me to fix it… I had to turn off all the after-processing features enabled by default, and put it into “PC-mode”. This was a samsung TV, but I’m sure you’ll have the same problem as it’s the same resolution/size and have had this crispy text problem for ages.

I don’t think the “PC mode” on my tv will work without me having VGA instead of HDMI. The pc-related settings are currently blacked out on the tv.
[/quote]
Have you tried all of the HDMI inputs on the tv?

I had to use the one labelled HDMI/DVI - this also disables sound, which I guess makes sense since DVI doesn’t usually carry sound. Maybe TVs can only treat the input as “PC” if they don’t have to deal with sound? Seems retarded but worked for me at least…[/quote]

sk8rdude461:

I’m using the sound though

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:23, topic:552260”][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=671176.msg4494722#msg4494722 date=1441042808]

try using catalyst to change the screen resolution on the tv itself, then check your tv for a widescreen/theater mode. it’s not always the aspect ratio

The screen is fit fine right now
Only problem left is that text isn’t that clear and can be hard to read.

I had the same problem as you and this topic inspired me to fix it… I had to turn off all the after-processing features enabled by default, and put it into “PC-mode”. This was a samsung TV, but I’m sure you’ll have the same problem as it’s the same resolution/size and have had this crispy text problem for ages.
[/quote]
I don’t think the “PC mode” on my tv will work without me having VGA instead of HDMI. The pc-related settings are currently blacked out on the tv.[/quote]
Have you tried all of the HDMI inputs on the tv?

I had to use the one labelled HDMI/DVI - this also disables sound, which I guess makes sense since DVI doesn’t usually carry sound. Maybe TVs can only treat the input as “PC” if they don’t have to deal with sound? Seems retarded but worked for me at least…

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

Try switching to VGA and use pc mode, get an adapter if you don’t have the port.

Read full topic

item.title: Display Resolution on a TV?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

my-swagger:

Out of curiosity, what connector are you using?

HDMI

[quote="-Nothing, post:21, topic:552260"]Is your just “HD-Ready” or FullHD? Because HD-ready TVs usually support 1080p but their native resolution is 720p which means 1080p looks like crap and it won’t function properly

Many years ago I was fooled by that marketing trick and I had the same kind of issues as you are having.[/quote]
Well this one supports 1080p… I never got thrown through some “marketing trick” because I got this tv from my great grandma’s house when we were cleaning it. So yeah.

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:22, topic:552260”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671176.msg4494663#msg4494663 date=1440980034]

try using catalyst to change the screen resolution on the tv itself, then check your tv for a widescreen/theater mode. it’s not always the aspect ratio

The screen is fit fine right now
Only problem left is that text isn’t that clear and can be hard to read.
[/quote]
I had the same problem as you and this topic inspired me to fix it… I had to turn off all the after-processing features enabled by default, and put it into “PC-mode”. This was a samsung TV, but I’m sure you’ll have the same problem as it’s the same resolution/size and have had this crispy text problem for ages.[/quote]
I don’t think the “PC mode” on my tv will work without me having VGA instead of HDMI. The pc-related settings are currently blacked out on the tv.

Read full topic
